channel.title: Brandon Boswell
channel.description: Recent content from Brandon Boswell's Digital Garden

item.title: write stuff you would love to read
item.description: • triggers intrinsic motivation so it doesn’t feel like work • more passionate writing = engaged readers , cus passion is contagious • when you share your interests, you attract your tribe
item.content:encoded: • triggers intrinsic motivation so it doesn’t feel like work • more passionate writing = engaged readers , cus passion is contagious • when you share your interests, you attract your tribe

item.title: There is a finite amount of energy available for making focused choices
Hold 45 Minutes A Day to Write
item.description: You don’t have to write, but you can’t do anything else. A key challenge I have with this if I prefer to write on the computer, and it’s filled with too many other distractions.
item.content:encoded:
You don’t have to write, but you can’t do anything else.

A key challenge I have with this if I prefer to write on the computer, and it’s filled with too many other distractions. The reMarkable could theoretically solve this with the reMarkable 2 Type Folio, but I find typing on it distracting.

Writing Writing as a habit

item.title: 7 habits of highly successful YouTubers
item.description: Author: Colin and Samir URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQ89d0ilocU Have an Athlete’s Mentality Hold 45 Minutes A Day to Write Ideally, any video you create would still be helpful in 10 years time.
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Colin and Samir
  • URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQ89d0ilocU

Have an Athlete’s Mentality Hold 45 Minutes A Day to Write Ideally, any video you create would still be helpful in 10 years time. If not, should you be producing that video?

YouTube

item.title: how to make a killer youtube intro (for the 2023 algorithm)
item.description: Author: Aprilynne Alter URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOHQXdCAo5k&t=4s YouTube Intro should be between 10 and 45 seconds Reiterate the Title in the first 5 seconds to minimize drop off Ideally the image from the intro matches that of the thumbnail (perhaps don’t start with my headshot?
item.content:encoded:
• Author: Aprilynne Alter
  • URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOHQXdCAo5k&t=4s

YouTube Intro should be between 10 and 45 seconds

Reiterate the Title in the first 5 seconds to minimize drop off

  • Ideally the image from the intro matches that of the thumbnail (perhaps don’t start with my headshot?)

The most successful videos exceed the title and thumbnail’s expectations

Create Curiosity Gaps to keep people watching

Provide Context so that everyone can participate even if they’re not an expert (I may have butchered this one)

Leverage Input Bias by communicating how much effort and time you put into the video so that the viewer will value the video.

Show people, don’t tell them. Give an intro that creates interest even if there isn’t audio. Frontload Stimulus. Many successful YouTubers change their intro visuals more than once every 2 seconds.

YouTube YouTube Formula

item.title: Nuphy Air75 V2
item.description: Nuphy Tricks: Unplug it and switch it into Wireless mode to allow for easy access to a USB-C Port. I use for getting audio off the Zoom F2 Recorder. Chef’s Kiss Also really nice for charging the reMarkable 2, which I don’t need to do often, but it’s nice not having to pull out another cable to do so.
item.content:encoded:
Nuphy Tricks:

  • Unplug it and switch it into Wireless mode to allow for easy access to a USB-C Port. I use for getting audio off the Zoom F2 Recorder. Chef’s Kiss
  • Also really nice for charging the reMarkable 2, which I don’t need to do often, but it’s nice not having to pull out another cable to do so.
  • I’m really enjoying the Mac/Windows switch when gaming at night on the keyboard
  • The stabilizers on this are a huge upgrade over those on the Lofree Flow

item.title: Notebooks vs Quick Sheets — When should you use each?
Tmux Session Manager
item.description: By Josh Medeski So good. If you’re a tmux user, then you should be using this. https://github.com/joshmedeski/t-smart-tmux-session-manager
item.content:encoded:
By Josh Medeski

So good. If you’re a tmux user, then you should be using this.

https://github.com/joshmedeski/t-smart-tmux-session-manager

item.title: VIM QuickFix Lists
item.description: :copen to open :ccl to clear :colder to grab the previous one :cnewer to grab the newer one :cdo run a command for each entry in the QuickFix ex: :cdo s/findstring/replacestring | update :cfdo runs once for each file in the quickfix list :vimgrep /yoursearch/ app/** To search a directory and put it in a Quick Fix List
item.content:encoded:
:copen to open :ccl to clear :colder to grab the previous one :cnewer to grab the newer one :cdo run a command for each entry in the QuickFix

  • ex: :cdo s/findstring/replacestring | update :cfdo runs once for each file in the quickfix list

:vimgrep /yoursearch/ app/** To search a directory and put it in a Quick Fix List

VIM Neovim

Source:

Andrew Courter https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuXZA-xCv04

item.title: Neovim
item.description: Switching to VIM might be one of the hardest things I’ve ever done Settings up Neovim checklist Use a simple distro, like LazyNvim Set up comfort of home shortcuts Use VIM Motions in your current editor for a week or two Get Tmux set up Close Buffer (CMD+W) Learn about IW and AW motions Learn about I and A Learn about Visual Mode Reopen last tab (CMD+SHIFT+T) Learn about Leap Set up Grep Live Args Learn about F and T Learn about / and * Install Vim Visual Multi Learn about Buffers and Windows and how they are different to tabs and tab panes Learn about QuickLists Learn about Telescope Learn about Registers and Marks Install Harpoon Use nvim not nvim * Learn about nvim-surround
item.content:encoded:
Switching to VIM might be one of the hardest things I’ve ever done

Settings up Neovim checklist

  • Use a simple distro, like LazyNvim
  • Set up comfort of home shortcuts
    • Use VIM Motions in your current editor for a week or two
    • Get Tmux set up
    • Close Buffer (CMD+W)
    • Learn about IW and AW motions
    • Learn about I and A
    • Learn about Visual Mode
    • Reopen last tab (CMD+SHIFT+T)
    • Learn about Leap
    • Set up Grep Live Args
    • Learn about F and T
    • Learn about / and *
    • Install Vim Visual Multi
    • Learn about Buffers and Windows and how they are different to tabs and tab panes
    • Learn about QuickLists
    • Learn about Telescope
    • Learn about Registers and Marks
    • Install Harpoon
    • Use nvim not nvim *
    • Learn about nvim-surround

item.title: How to search for files on the terminal
item.description: Install fzf find . -type f | fzf --preview 'less {}' You can also do this with ripgrep rg --files -g '!*.spec*' -g '!*.scss' | rg modal
item.content:encoded:
Install fzf

find . -type f | fzf --preview 'less {}'

You can also do this with ripgrep rg --files -g '!*.spec*' -g '!*.scss' | rg modal

item.title: If all of your time is planned, you leave no room for serendipity and spontaneity
Practical Success Metrics
item.description: It’s a bit like Functional Strength in exercise. Instead of focusing on being able to lift a ton of weight, focus on being able to do the crucial things in your life.
item.content:encoded: It’s a bit like Functional Strength in exercise. Instead of focusing on being able to lift a ton of weight, focus on being able to do the crucial things in your life.

item.title: The 100ms Rule
item.description: The creator of Gmail, Paul Buchheit, had a rule: every interaction should be faster than 100ms. Why? Because 100ms is the threshold where interactions feel instantaneous.
item.content:encoded: The creator of Gmail, Paul Buchheit, had a rule: every interaction should be faster than 100ms. Why? Because 100ms is the threshold where interactions feel instantaneous.
